The Cabinet discussed, in its political .andother aspects, the Liberal Amendment to the Land TaxClauses of the Finance Bill to be moved on Wednesday next, June 17th, and the attitude to be adopted bythe Government towards it.The Cabinet were informed that the intention ofthe Liberal Pa^ty was to re-draft the Amendmentalready handed in.The subject was adjourned untilthe next Meeting. fid2. The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs informed the Cabinet that after very careful consid-eration he had decided that it would not be advisable to adopt the suggestion of the British High Commis-sioner in egypt to issue a public statement withthe object of bringing about conciliation betweenthe various parties in egypt. However carefullyworded, such a statement would be liable tomisinterpretation, either by one side or the other.He thought it better to adhere closely to ourpublicly-declared policy of non-intervention inEgypt's internal squabbles. He had sent a telegram to this effect to Sir Percy Loraine (No.169 of June9th) . THE FRENCH 3. The Secretary of State for Foreign AffairsCOLONIALEXHIBITION, informed the Cabinet that the French Government were anxious to welcome some members of the United KingdomGovernment on a visit to the Paris InternationalColonial Exhibition. In this connection he referredto a circular that had been issued from the cabinet office on May 26th. A "British Week" was to be held between the l^th and 19th July, and it was hopedthat the Prince of Wales might pay a visit towardsthe end of that week. The Secretary of State wouldbe very glad if any of his colleagues could possiblyfind it convenient to visit the Exhibition. He himself would be visiting Geneva on July 13th, and. he proposedto leave London two days earlier in order to enable him to pay a visit to the Exhibition.The Cabinet approved these arrangements. european0ion.?he Inter-f.tionalnf,riculturalMortgageCredits(previous reference:Cabinet 27/SI). At this meetingthe Secretary of State had expressed approval ofthe scheme but had foreseen certain difficultiesfrom the point o^ view of the United Kingdom andhad undertaken to lay the matter before His Majesty'sGovernment for consideration. He gave reasons forrecommending the acceptance of the Convention byHis Ma j e st y* s G overranent in t he United Kingdom,including a proposed contribution of - 120,000towards a special reserve fund of 1,^000,000 to becontributed by all the Governments parties to theConvention.The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs mentioned that this proposal had only come to his knowledge after he had arrived at Geneva for ameeting of the Commission of Inquiry for european union. He had at once taken steps to ensure thathis colleagues at. home were made fully aware of allthe circumstances.The Cabinet were reminded that when particulars of the proposal had first been received, some doubtshad been felt as to the political expediency of taking part in a scheme devised with the object of facilitating the transfer of agriculture in central and Eastern European countries from cereal to mixedfarming at a time when cereal farming was indistress in this country as well as in the Dominions. There was general agreement, however, that the case for participation was strong, even though suchparticipation might be used to emphasise, by con-trast, the need for stimulating agriculture in thiscountry.The Cabinet agreed --To approve the acceptance of theConvention, including the proposedcontribution towards the reserve fund to be made by all the Govern-ments parties to the Convention. The Cabinet took note of a statement by theSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs that sir Walter Layton had accepted his invitation to sit on the proposed Economic Committee as thenominee of His Majesty's Government, on certain conditions which the Secretary of State had felt able to accept . 6"^The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (CP.-147(31)) raising the question as to whether Fis Majesty*sGovernment should, participate in the proceedings before the Hague Court regarding the validity of theproposed Austro-Gerroan Customs Union. It was statedin the Memorandum that the idea of our co-operating in the presentation of a joint Case either with theFrench or with any other o^ the interested Governmentswas excluded, as the United Kingdom case could not beregarded as identical with the French. Strong argu-ments were given in the memorandum \im both for and against separate British participation in the proceed-ings before the Hague JXourt......After a full examination of the issues, theCabinet agreed (a) That the policy should be as--fa"r-aspossible to maintain a neutralposition in the controversy beforethe Hague- Court, in order that theGovernment might remain in the best position possible to exercise itsgood offices in finding a solution to the political issues involvedwhich v-otild arise Subsequent to the findings o.^ the Court, and that thispolicy could best be advanced byavoiding participation in the pro-ceedings before the Hague Court:fb) That the Secretary $f State forForeign Affairs should suggest tothe Court the adoption of a methodof inquiry customary in correspondingcases in this country, that is to say,that documents such, as the protocol of 1922 and the Treaty of Saint Germainshould be submitted to the Court withoutpleading, and that the Court should only ask for such further assistance as it requires . That course, "\t was felt, would provide a helpful e&plana-tion to foreign countries as to thedecision not to take part in pleadings:, - .. f .i(c) That the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs should explain theposition to the Governments of Franceand Gzecho-Slovakia, making clear thereasons for our desire to retain a neutral and unbiassed position. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum byRELATING to international the Secretary of State for Air (C.P.-130 (31))CARRIAGE by air. covering a Convention for the Unification of certainf-K. Rules relating to International Carriage by Air,signed at Warsaw in October, 1929. The Secretaryof State asked for authority to ratify the convention and submitted (in paragraph 10) the following pro-posals for the approval of the Cabinet:-(a) That His Majesty's Government should announce their willingness to ratify the Convention subject to generalreadiness on the part of other signatory States to ratify it andto the passing by Parliament of thelegislation necessary to give effectto it;(b) That His Majesty's Government should,at the same time, announce that theydo not propose to exercise the rightof reservation as regards State-performedcarriage given by the Additional Protocol;(c) That the legislation to be introduced to give effect to the Convention should provide for the application of its rules(with any necessary modifications) to internal, as well as international,carriage by air; and(d) That this legislation should also take appropriate power to apply these rulesto intra-Imperial carriage by air.The Cabinet agreed - To approve the ratification of theConvention, subject to arrangements to be made by the Secretary of Statefor Air with the Secretary of Statefor Dominion Affairs, the Secretaryof State for the Colonies and theSecretary of State for India, as tothe extent to which such ratificationis made applicable to the Dominions,Colonies and India. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum bythe Secretary for Mines (CP.-145 (31)) dealing withthe Mines Department Emergency Organisation relative to the conservation and distribution of fuel duringan emergency of the nature contemplated by theEmergency Powers Act, 1920. The question was raised as to whether the Secretary for Mines should beauthorised to consult, under the seal of secrecy,(a) the coal owners, and (b) the coal factors and coal merchants, as to the personnel of committees which would only function if there was a nationalstoppage. It was stated that without such consult,a-tion the emergency organisation cannot be completed and some risk will be taken of chaotic conditions inthe early stages of a coal strike if it occurs.The Cabinet agreed (a) That the Home Secretary, the Presidentof the Board of Trade and the Secretaryof State for Scotland, with authorityto incite the co-operation of other ministers as required, should giveinter-Departmental consideration tothe Emergency Organisation and reportto the Cabinet at their next Meeting:(b) That in the meantime no communication should be made to the coal-owners orcoal factors and coal merchants. rnjfTF IRON ANDSTEEL TRADE.Re-or.erahi39t-i.ori(previous reference:Oa' inet SO(31), Oon-oiusion 6.)9.. In favour of theformer course it was pointed out that a DepartmentalCommittee could be composed of persons who would consider the question purely on its merits and withoutpolitical bias., whereaa a Select Committee w-as likelyto divide on Party lines. On the other hand it was urged that the question was already very importantpolitically and was likely to become more so in theimmediate future.
